title: The Psychology of Curiosity: A Review and Reinterpretation
summary: Curiosity is a feeling of deprivation arising from a gap between what we know and what we want to know. This gap produces a drive (similar to hunger) to obtain the missing information.

effectiveness_metrics.description: Subsequent research (Kang et al., 2009) confirmed curiosity activates the brain's reward circuitry (SN/VTA) and enhances memory.

mechanisms.name: Cognitive Deprivation
mechanisms.description: The uncomfortable/itching feeling of not knowing something, which drives action.

mechanisms.name: Reward Prediction
mechanisms.description: Closing the gap provides a hit of satisfaction (dopamine).

mechanisms.name: Inverted-U
mechanisms.description: Curiosity is highest when we know a little bit, but not everything (the 'zone of proximal development' for interest).

actionable_strategies.name: Curiosity Bite
actionable_strategies.application_in_app: Instead of a blocker, show a card: 'Do you know the one weird reason [Topic] works? Click to see.' (Redirects to study material).

actionable_strategies.name: Question-First Learning
actionable_strategies.application_in_app: Prompt the user to guess the answer to a relevant question before starting work, priming the brain for learning.
